answers: says it's too bad they could not be located and attempts to go back to camp.

Text.text: Please don't assume that I know what a Qornt is or who Magnan is. Either of these seem possible.
Magnan, regardless of who he is, directly states that it's a pity the Qornt couldn't be found and then tells his partner that they shall return back to camp.
The second Magnan sees the Qornt, he turns around and runs away for help, as the text directly states.

I'm leaning towards B mostly because the evidence presented by Debater A cuts off mid sentence and the evidence from B seems to indicate that Magnan at least encountered Qornt once (albeit the line numbers indicate a passage of time). 
To Deb A: Can you tell me what happens immediately after your quote? And also inform why potentially something else happens between your quote and B's quote to explain how Magnan met the Qornt. 
To Deb B: Can you tell me why the quote from A is incomplete or misused, and also add evidence that Magnan encountered Qornt at the same time they were 'trying to locate them'

The question asks what happens after "a short time of trying to locate the Qornt" meaning my burden is just to prove what happens initially. Even if, after some long amount of time, the Qornt are located that wouldn't answer the question of what happened after the initial attempt of finding them.

Right after the quote, Retief (Magnan's partner) cuts Magnan off and tries to keep searching but Magnan **attempts to go back to camp** and criticizes Retief for trying to keep looking.

The discussion which Shreeram mentions between Magan and Retief occurs almost concurrently with the evidence that I presented in my first speech. The only thing that separates them is a few lines of dialogue, so for all intents and purposes of this debate, all my evidence can be considered to have happened "after a short time" as well. 

However, when it comes to Shreeram's argument, it is false that Magnan "attempts" to go back to camp. An "attempt" is defined as "an act of trying to achieve something," so Magnan must perform the act of going back to camp in order for Shreeram's point to be valid. However, there is no evidence within this "short time" which indicates that Magnan did such a thing. Right after the conversation, which ends at

Leaning further towards B, the wording seems to point out that the camp is safe and Magnan wants to retreat to safety. 
So what I know is that Magnan says the original A-quote.
And then (From A's current quote) Retief instead offers that they split up - Magnan to go to the boat, and Retief to go over and observe something potentially dangerous. Then the interruption comes (quote from B), where a Qornt attacks i.e. Magnan finds the Qornt. 
Am I misunderstanding the reconstruction? Correct me if something I'm inferring is wrong or provide any information I'm missing.

It's not a question of the reconstruction but rather what the question is asking. I.e. Magnan directly states that it's too bad the Qorn't couldn't be found and then attempts to go back to camp. Even if the Qornt are later found, the incident that occurs first is that Magnan tries to go back to the camp.

Magnan, by urging Retief to return back to camp is making an attempt at returning. Even if the attempt is unsuccessful (whether that's because of Retief stopping him or any other reason) it's still an attempt and means that A is the correct response.

Shreeram just asserts that what Magnan is making an attempt and completely ignoring the definition that I provide, which defines an "attempt" as an "act" which has to be done, Shreeram never identifies an "act" which Magnan performs, so you even if you don't believe my side, you also can't believe his side because Magnan never makes an "attempt," so he never satisfies the constraints of the question. Shreeram later makes the analysis that his incident occurs before mine, but this is irrelevant to the question, the question is not asking what happened first. 

However, there is proof that Magnan finds the Qornt and runs, this goes uncontested from Shreeram, so in the scope of this debate, all of my evidence should be considered true. The judge's reconstruction is correct, Magnan never makes a substantive attempt to return to the camp.
A could be true but then B would have to be false, whereas B can be true along with A. I am voting on this logic, as both have sufficient textual ev.
